Class Display

  • java.lang.Object
    • Display
  • public class Display
extends java.lang.Object
    This class is part of the ToDo application. ToDo is a very simple, text based todo list application. This class bring everything together and deals with main functionality of the program.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      Display()
      Constructor of Display class.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      void addTask()
      Method adds the Task into the list of tasks.
      void editDate()
      User can select a Task and change its due date.
      void editName()
      User can select a Task and change its name
      void editProject()
      User can select a Project a specific task is assigned to and change its name
      void editTask()
      Method contains all functionality that goes into editing a task...
      void getTaskNumberAndChangeItToDone()
      Method changes status of task from PENDING to DONE.
      void orderListOptions()
      Method is responsible for functionality on what what happens depending on how the user wants to sort the list.
      void quitAndSave()
      Method quits the application and saves the file.
      void removeTask()
      Method removes a task requested from a user from the list.
      void response()
      Method with the main routine that will keep program running until user wants to quit.
      void start()
      Method that welcomes the user into the application and gives them possible options.
      void update()
      Method had functionality of editing name, editing project and a editing due date.
      java.lang.String userInput()
      Method asks for user input and returns it.

      • addTask

        public void addTask()
        Method adds the Task into the list of tasks. It records the date task was created and correct user if he/she enter dueDate in wrong format.

        Method quits the application and saves the file.
